1. Check the order in which you are specifying the vertices of the triangle. By default, OpenGL uses counter-clockwise winding order to determine which side of a triangle is facing the camera. If the vertices are specified in a clockwise order, OpenGL will render the back face of the triangle instead of the front face. To fix this, you can either change the winding order of the vertices or use the `glFrontFace()` function to specify a different winding order.

2. Another issue could be related to the projection matrix. Make sure that you are setting the projection matrix correctly in the `render()` function. You can use the `glMatrixMode()` and `glLoadIdentity()` functions to reset the matrix and set the correct perspective.

3. Finally, check the vertex shader code to ensure that it is correctly transforming the vertices to the correct position on the screen. You can use the `gl_Position` variable to set the position of the vertex in clip coordinates.

Try these fixes and see if they solve the problem with the triangle rendering.<eom>
